newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ SPORT-CRICKET-Final chance for NZ batsmen in 5th ODI.
newsitem.headline: NZ SPORT-CRICKET-Final chance for NZ batsmen in 5th ODI.

text.p: AUCKLAND, March 3 - New Zealand have one final chance to get their undisciplined batting lineup in shape if they want to square the one-day cricket series against England at the Basin Reserve in Wellington on Tuesday.
When New Zealand pulled England's lead back to 2-1 in the five-game series -- the third match in Napier was tied -- it was entirely due to the sterling work of their bowlers and fielders.
Once again the batsmen failed to deliver.
New Zealand were bowled out for 153, squandering a promising 113 for two in the 26th over of the 43-over match.
Eight wickets fell in 82 balls for the addition of just 40 runs.

Two were run out, two fell to leading edges in one over from offspinner Robert Croft, one drove at a wide delivery, another popped an easy catch to mid off while the tail-enders had no chance against good, full length deliveries.
"The batting has only done it once out of four times so far in the series," captain Lee Germon said last night.
"That was at Auckland (in the second match) when we got 250 and that was down to Chris Cairns scoring 80.
"We do need to keep working on the batting."
Germon didn't believe a sense of panic set in yesterday and the players became over-eager to get quick runs in the middle stages of their innings.
Nevertheless, New Zealand batting collapses have been a regular feature of the home season.
There were four significant mid-innings flops in six innings during the three-test series against England, while the one-day form has scarcely been a cause for celebration.
New Zealand coach Steve Rixon said England had shown their batting frailties as well in the one-dayers.
"They've collapsed every time they've had the opportunity, just as we have -- but we've set targets that were more gettable," he said.
"We know what we've got to do, we'll go about our match plan, and concentrate a bit harder.
"Now we've got a base, we know how to win a game."
The bowlers did an excellent rescue job for New Zealand yesterday.
New ball pair Heath Davis and Geoff Allott, although not particularly inexpensive, each chipped out two wickets to have England 41 for four in the ninth over.
Then Gavin Larsen, Chris Harris, Nathan Astle and Simon Doull combined to choke off the run supply as Alec Stewart and Craig White set about a rescue mission, adding 50 for the fifth wicket.
After Astle and Harris nipped out those two batsmen, Larsen grabbed three wickets with his last eight deliveries -- along with Robert Croft's run out -- to keep New Zealand afloat in the series.
But that win had nothing to do with the New Zealand batsmen, who again showed an inability to kick on from a sound start.
Openers Bryan Young and Astle got 53 in 65 balls, then Astle and Stephen Fleming put on a further 59 in 84 balls for the third wicket.
England led the series 2-0 and seemed sure to take a one-day series win home to go with their 2-0 test victory.
Now they've got some work to do after the tied match in Napier and yesterday's defeat.
"The tour is winding down a little. We've got one game to raise ourselves for before we go home and we're keen to wrap up the series in Wellington," captain Mike Atherton said last night.
But Atherton was quick to point out his team hadn't gifted away a 2-0 lead.
"There's two teams playing and there's no divine right to win," he added.
"If you play a bit below par, as we did when we batted today, you give New Zealand a chance.
"They took that chance today."
England opener Nick Knight is out of the tour after breaking his left index finger on the first ball of the England innings yesterday.
It's likely batsman John Crawley will return in his place.
Fast-medium bowler Dominic Cork missed yesterday's game with a twinge in a leg.
It is unclear whether he will be fit for tomorrow's match.
The game will be watched by a sellout crowd of about 13,000.
The umpires are Evan Watkin of Wellington and Dunedin's Steve Dunne with Christchurch's Dave Quested the third official.
Teams:

New Zealand: Lee Germon (captain), Bryan Young, Nathan Astle, Stephen Fleming, Chris Cairns, Adam Parore, Chris Harris, Dipak Patel, Gavin Larsen, Simon Doull, Heath Davis, Geoff Allott (one to be omitted).

England: Mike Atherton (captain), Alec Stewart, Graham Thorpe, Nasser Hussain, John Crawley, Ronnie Irani, Craig White, Dominic Cork, Robert Croft, Darren Gough, Andrew Caddick, Chris Silverwood, Alan Mullally, Phil Tufnell, Jack Russell (four to be omitted).
